results.title: Colour of war
results.creator_credit: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Transworld International and Carlton Television
results.brief_description: Almost all our recollections of the Second World War are in black and white. But years of research have unearthed hours of previously unseen colour film offering a completely new portrait of the war. The result is ‘Colour Of War’ a remarkable insight into the event that has shaped our modern world. Dramatic colour footage from as early as 1933 shows home movies of Adolf Hitler and his co-horts, the devastation wrought by the Blitz, life on the home front, D-Day and the Allied Invasion of France, British bombers defying German fighters, the horror of the Holocaust that greeted troops as they entered Germany and the jubilation of VE Day. With John Thaw’s narration and spoken accounts from the letters and diaries of those who fought, those who survived, and those the war claimed as victims, this three part documentary is an extraordinary remembrance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Transworld International and Carlton Television

results.title: Colour of war [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Transworld International and Carlton Television
results.brief_description:
Almost all our recollections of the Second World War are in black and white. But years of research have unearthed hours of previously unseen colour film offering a completely new portrait of the war. The result is ‘Colour Of War’ a remarkable insight into the event that has shaped our modern world. Dramatic colour footage from as early as 1933 shows home movies of Adolf Hitler and his co-horts, the devastation wrought by the Blitz, life on the home front, D-Day and the Allied Invasion of France, British bombers defying German fighters, the horror of the Holocaust that greeted troops as they entered Germany and the jubilation of VE Day. With John Thaw’s narration and spoken accounts from the letters and diaries of those who fought, those who survived, and those the war claimed as victims, this three part documentary is an extraordinary remembrance.
1. ‘A new world order’ Reccollections of those involved during the pre-war turmoil of 1930s when the rhetoric of ideology and extremism was increasingly being heard. Highlights include combat footage of the Spanish Civil War, the coronation of King George VI in 1937, spectacular mass rallies in Germany and the Soviet Union and the images of the devastation of the Blitz in Great Britain.
2. ‘Total War’ Focuses on the period when the war reached a new, global intensity, beginning with the bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941 and ending in the Summer of 1944 with US Marines fighting bloody battles with the Japanese in the Pacific.
3. ‘Triumph and despair’ The experiences of British, American and Canadian soldiers, who made the historic crossing of the Channel, and who fought through The Battle of the Hedgerows to liberate Northern France, are heard through their letters and diaries. The fears and emotions expressed by American, French and Japanese soldiers and Japanese and German civilians are accompanied by footage of the fall of Berlin, the Battle of Okinawa, Kamikaze attacks and the devastation of the Atom bomb. This volume concludes with footage of the release of POWs, refugees and displaced people and reflects on the legacy of a war which cost 50 million lives.

Also available on VHS [313552], [313553], and [313554].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Transworld International and Carlton Television

results.title: Colour bars
results.creator_credit: Fabio Cavadini, Mandy King and Auburn Community Development Network
results.brief_description: This non-observational documentary made for SBS Independent is about the lives of five young Australians of non-English Speaking Backgrounds. They were born or raised in Australia and have experienced the ups and downs of growing up in at least two cultures; that of their parents and the mainstream culture.

results.title: Joan Lindsay
results.creator_credit: Ian McKay, Australia Council and AAV Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
In this interview with John Taylor, Joan Lindsay speaks about her experiences as an art student at the National Gallery School in Melbourne and her decision to become a writer. She talks about her marriage to the painter Daryl Lindsay. Lindsay describes the process of writing her novel, “Picnic at Hanging Rock”, and her preoccupation with time as a theme. Related to both the Boyd and Lindsay families, she gives a unique insight into the personalities of some of Australia’s leading artists.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian McKay, Australia Council and AAV Australia

results.title: Robert D. Fitzgerald
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Acclaimed poet Robert D. Fitzgerald describes himself as a “professional surveyor and an amateur poet”. He recalls his experiences working for the Native Lands Commission in the remote interior regions of Fiji which inspired his poem “Between two tides”. Fitzgerald remembers his friendship with fellow writers Kenneth Slessor, Jack and Phillip Lindsay, Douglas Stewart and Dame Mary Gilmore. During the Vietnam war, Fitzgerald was active in the anti-war movement. He discusses the reasons for his involvement and recalls the events surrounding the Arts Vietnam protest.

results.title: Jack Lindsay
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Jack Lindsay speaks about his relationship with his father, Norman Lindsay, and their shared interest in the classical world. He recalls the cultural life of Sydney in the 1920s and his memories of writers Kenneth Slessor, Christopher Brennan and Henry Lawson. Lindsay left Australia in 1926 and remained in England for the rest of his life. A poet, novelist, translator, historian, critic and biographer, Lindsay discusses the influence of political thought on his writing and his involvement in the anti-Facist Union of Poets and the Authors’ World Peace Appeal. He remembers his friendships with fellow poets Dylan Thomas, Edith Sitwell, Aragon, Tristan Tzara and Paul Eluard.

results.title: Olaf Ruhen
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch, author Olaf Ruhen recalls a life travelling throughout Australia and the South Pacific gathering materials for his books. He speaks of his love of the sea and his affinity with the Tongan people. Ruhen recalls his friendship with the painter, Albert Namatjira. A visit to a writers’ conference in New York inspired Ruhen to create a forum for Australian authors, the Australian Society of Authors.

results.title: Colourful notions (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Colour vision must have evolved to serve some practical purpose. Dr. Edwin Lord has a new theory that colour is not the property of objects at all but the result of complex calculations which the brain performs to ensure that objects can be recognized under a wide range of light conditions
